P.title: Will someone hold their breath for more than 30 minutes before 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, there is a verifiable report of an individual holding their breath for more than 30 consecutive minutes under the following conditions:

- The individual must be submerged in water or in a controlled environment that simulates submersion, without the use of any breathing apparatus or external oxygen supply.

- The attempt must be continuously monitored and recorded by an independent organization recognized for certifying breath-holding records, such as the Guinness World Records or AIDA International (Association for the Development of Apnea).

- The individual must be conscious and alert throughout the duration of the attempt, and medical professionals must confirm the individual's well-being immediately following the attempt.

- The use of any performance-enhancing drugs or medical procedures specifically aimed at increasing breath-holding capacity is not permitted.

- In the event of a tie, where multiple individuals meet the criteria on the same day, the question will resolve as Yes for each individual.

- If no verifiable report is presented by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if SpaceX successfully lands a spacecraft, rover, or any other type of equipment on the surface of Mars before January 1, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by SpaceX through an official announcement or live feed, and corroborated by at least one of the following: NASA, the European Space Agency (ESA), or an independent space monitoring authority recognized by the International Astronautical Federation (IAF). In the event of a dispute regarding the success of the landing, the resolution will be based on the consensus of at least two of the aforementioned organizations. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution criteria will apply to the successor organization responsible for continuing the Mars mission. Should the landing occur but not be publicly disclosed before the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

P_or_Q.title: Will someone hold their breath for more than 30 minutes before 2025 or will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of these events happen. a.) There is a verifiable report of an individual holding their breath for more than 30 consecutive minutes before January 1, 2025 under specific conditions OR b.) SpaceX successfully lands a spacecraft, rover, or any other type of equipment on the surface of Mars before January 1, 2030. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030 or will someone hold their breath for more than 30 minutes before 2025?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of these events happen. a.) SpaceX successfully lands a spacecraft, rover, or any other type of equipment on the surface of Mars before January 1, 2030 OR b.) there is a verifiable report of an individual holding their breath for more than 30 consecutive minutes before January 1, 2025 under the specified conditions. Resolves NO otherwise.

reasoning:
Symmetry Or reasoning:
P_or_Q reasoning:
The event of someone holding their breath for more than 30 minutes before 2025 or SpaceX landing anything on Mars before 2030 is the disjunction of the two individual events.
Q_or_P reasoning:
The event of either SpaceX landing something on Mars before 2030 or someone holding their breath for more than 30 minutes before 2025 is the disjunction of P and Q.

P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, on December 31, 2033, the net worth of the richest person in the world, as listed by Forbes' annual billionaires list, is equal to or exceeds 2% of the United States' Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for the year 2033. The GDP will be determined based on the data released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. In the event that Forbes does not release a billionaires list for the year 2033, the resolution will be based on the most widely recognized and credible alternative source available at the time. If the BEA has not released the GDP data for 2033 by December 31, 2033, the resolution will be based on the most recent and reliable estimate available from a recognized economic research institution. In the case of any discrepancies between sources or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of economic experts, whose decision will be final.

not_P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 not have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, on December 31, 2033, the net worth of the richest person in the world, as listed by Forbes' annual billionaires list, is less than 2% of the United States' Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for the year 2033. The GDP will be determined based on the data released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. In the event that Forbes does not release a billionaires list for the year 2033, the resolution will be based on the most widely recognized and credible alternative source available at the time. If the BEA has not released the GDP data for 2033 by December 31, 2033, the resolution will be based on the most recent and reliable estimate available from a recognized economic research institution. In the case of any discrepancies between sources or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of economic experts, whose decision will be final.

reasoning: The two questions are indeed the negation of each other. If the richest person's net worth is equal to or exceeds 2% of the US GDP, then the negation would be that the net worth is less than 2% of the US GDP, and vice versa.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1, 2035, any country that possessed nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, has officially disarmed its nuclear arsenal and has been confirmed to have done so by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The disarmament must include the dismantlement of all nuclear warheads and the cessation of production of nuclear weapons materials. The IAEA must have been granted full access to verify the disarmament process and must have published a report confirming the completion of disarmament. If a country has transferred its nuclear weapons to another state or entity, or if it has only partially dismantled its arsenal, the question will resolve as No. In the event that the IAEA is dissolved or unable to perform verification, an equivalent authoritative international body must confirm the disarmament for the question to resolve as Yes.

Q.title: Will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2035, Puerto Rico is officially admitted as a state of the United States of America. The admission must be recognized by the U.S. Congress, and Puerto Rico must be granted full representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate. The resolution will be based on the passage of a statehood admission act by Congress, the signing of such an act by the President of the United States, and the subsequent certification of statehood by the U.S. Secretary of State. In the event of any legal disputes or challenges regarding the admission process, the question will not resolve until all such disputes are conclusively settled in favor of statehood. If Puerto Rico is offered statehood but the offer is not accepted by the Puerto Rican government or its people through a referendum, the question will resolve as No.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035 AND will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of these events happen. a.) By January 1, 2035, any country that possessed nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, has officially disarmed its nuclear arsenal and has been confirmed to have done so by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) AND b.) Before January 1, 2035, Puerto Rico is officially admitted as a state of the United States of America. The admission must be recognized by the U.S. Congress, and Puerto Rico must be granted full representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate. The resolution will be based on the passage of a statehood admission act by Congress, the signing of such an act by the President of the United States, and the subsequent certification of statehood by the U.S. Secretary of State. In the event of any legal disputes or challenges regarding the admission process, the question will not resolve until all such disputes are conclusively settled in favor of statehood. If Puerto Rico is offered statehood but the offer is not accepted by the Puerto Rican government or its people through a referendum, the question will resolve as No. Resolves NO otherwise.

reasoning: The event of any country giving up nuclear weapons and Puerto Rico becoming a US state are independent events and not related to each other. Therefore, the probability of both events happening is not the conjunction of the individual events.

The admission must be recognized by the U.S. Congress, and Puerto Rico must be granted full representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate. Resolves NO otherwise.

reasoning: In this scenario, the relationships between P, Q, R, and S are logically consistent and plausible. R combines the question about Puerto Rico becoming a US state with the negation of the question about any country giving up nuclear weapons before 2035. S is true if either event happens. The definitions for R as Puerto Rico becoming a US state and not any country giving up nuclear weapons, and S as either event occurring, are logically coherent.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1, 2035, any country that possessed nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, has officially disarmed its nuclear arsenal and has been confirmed to have done so by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The disarmament must include the dismantlement of all nuclear warheads and the cessation of production of nuclear weapons materials. The IAEA must have been granted full access to verify the disarmament process and must have published a report confirming the completion of disarmament. If a country has transferred its nuclear weapons to another state or entity, or if it has only partially dismantled its arsenal, the question will resolve as No. In the event that the IAEA is dissolved or unable to perform verification, an equivalent authoritative international body must confirm the disarmament for the question to resolve as Yes.

Q_given_P.title: Given that any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017, gives them up before 2035, will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017, gives them up before 2035. If the condition is met (if any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017, gives them up before 2035), then resolves YES if Puerto Rico becomes a US state prior to 2035 and NO if it does not. The resolution for Puerto Rico becoming a US state is based on specific criteria including recognition by the U.S. Congress, full representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate, and certification of statehood by the U.S. Secretary of State.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035 AND will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of these events happen. a.) By January 1, 2035, any country that possessed nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, has officially disarmed its nuclear arsenal and has been confirmed to have done so by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) AND b.) Before January 1, 2035, Puerto Rico is officially admitted as a state of the United States of America. The admission must be recognized by the U.S. Congress, and Puerto Rico must be granted full representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate. The resolution will be based on the passage of a statehood admission act by Congress, the signing of such an act by the President of the United States, and the subsequent certification of statehood by the U.S. Secretary of State. In the event of any legal disputes or challenges regarding the admission process, the question will not resolve until all such disputes are conclusively settled in favor of statehood. If Puerto Rico is offered statehood but the offer is not accepted by the Puerto Rican government or its people through a referendum, the question will resolve as No.

reasoning: The relationships between P, Q, R, and S are logically consistent and plausible. R represents the conditional probability of Q given P, and S represents the conjunction of P and Q. The conditions for R and S align with the definitions provided for conditional probability and conjunction.

cons_P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 still possess them in 2035?
cons_P.body: Resolves YES if, by January 1, 2035, any country that possessed nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, still has them in their possession. Resolves NO otherwise.

reasoning: If a country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 gives them up before 2035 (P), then it logically follows that they will not possess them in 2035 (Q). Conversely, if a country still possesses nuclear weapons in 2035, it implies that they did not give them up before 2035. Therefore, Q is logically contingent on P being true.

P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, on December 31, 2033, the net worth of the richest person in the world, as listed by Forbes' annual billionaires list, is equal to or exceeds 2% of the United States' Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for the year 2033. The GDP will be determined based on the data released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. In the event that Forbes does not release a billionaires list for the year 2033, the resolution will be based on the most widely recognized and credible alternative source available at the time. If the BEA has not released the GDP data for 2033 by December 31, 2033, the resolution will be based on the most recent and reliable estimate available from a recognized economic research institution. In the case of any discrepancies between sources or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of economic experts, whose decision will be final.

para_P.title: By December 31, 2033, will the wealthiest individual globally have a net worth equal to or exceeding 2% of the United States' GDP for that year?
para_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, on December 31, 2033, the richest person globally, as identified by the annual billionaires list published by Forbes, possesses a net worth that is at least 2% of the United States' Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for the year 2033. The determination of GDP will be based on the data provided by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) under the U.S. Department of Commerce. If Forbes does not release a billionaires list for 2033, an alternative reputable source will be used. If the BEA has not published the GDP data for 2033 by the deadline, the most recent reliable estimate from a recognized economic research institution will be utilized. In cases of data discrepancies or unavailability, a panel of economic experts will make the final decision.

reasoning: Both questions inquire about the net worth of the richest person in the world compared to the United States' GDP in 2033. Despite slight differences in wording, the essential inquiry remains the same, focusing on the wealth comparison. Therefore, they are paraphrases of each other.
